column1: Sentence
Arthritis is inflammation of one or more joints.
Arthritis may occur in men or women.
Arthritis causes joint pain, swelling, stiffness, and limited movement.
The health care provider will perform a physical exam and ask questions about your medical history.
Blood tests and joint x-rays are often done to check for infection and other causes of arthritis.
The goal of treatment is to reduce pain, improve function, and prevent further joint damage.
Exercise can help relieve stiffness, reduce pain and fatigue, and improve muscle and bone strength.
- Eat foods rich in omega-3 fatty acids, such as cold water fish (salmon, mackerel, and herring), flaxseed, rapeseed (canola) oil, soybeans, soybean oil, pumpkin seeds, and walnuts.
Weight loss can greatly improve joint pain in the legs and feet.
Over-the-counter medicines: - Acetaminophen (Tylenol) is often the first medicine tried.
- Aspirin, ibuprofen, or naproxen are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) that can relieve arthritis pain.
Prescription medicines: - Biologics are used for the treatment of autoimmune arthritis.
They include etanercept (Enbrel), infliximab (Remicade), adalimumab (Humira), abatacept (Orencia), rituximab (Rituxan), golimumab (Simponi), certolizumab (Cimzia), and tocilizumab (Actemra).
These drugs can improve the quality of life for many patients, but can have serious side effects.
- Corticosteroids ("steroids") help reduce inflammation.
- Disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are used to treat autoimmune arthritis.
- Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine or cyclophosphamide are used to treat patients with rheumatoid arthritis when other medications have not worked.
- For gout, allopurinol (Zyloprim) or febuxostat (Uloric) may be used to lower uric acid.
Also make sure your doctor knows about all the medicines you are taking, including vitamins and supplements bought without a prescription.
SURGERY AND OTHER TREATMENTS In some cases, surgery may be done if other treatments have not worked.
This may include: - Joint replacement, such as a total knee joint replacement
A few arthritis-related disorders can be completely cured with proper treatment.
If you have a family history of arthritis, tell your doctor, even if you do not have joint pain.
